bibl.title: Letter from Charles W. Comstock to George Schobinger, September 11, 1922

div1.p: Comstock describes possible yellow fever cases to Schobinger. All involve foreigners in Brazil. Comstock criticizes the local physicians' attitude and treatment of the cases.

div1.head: Letter from Charles W. Comstock to George Schobinger, September 11, 1922
div1.opener:
COPY
No. 213
Fortaleza, September 11, 1922
Mr. George Schobinger
Dwight P. Robinson & Co., Inc.
Caixa Postal 69
Rio de Janeiro.
My dear Schobinger:
div1.p:
Your letter of August 14 explaining your telegraphic inquiry for
information about deaths reported to be due to yellow fever, arrived just as
I was about to leave for the interior and had to wait until my return for a
reply.

You can readily understand that we have very little real information
about any of these cases, being dependent on the statements of the physicians,
who are frequently at variance, and in no position to judge among them.

The first case that came to my attention was that of C.D. Ashmore,
representative of the American Locomotive Co., who arrived here on May 6, 1921,
and died May 31. Ashmore was not more than fifty years old (perhaps not more
than forty-five) appeared robust and active and spoke of being in excellent
health. He did not touch any alcoholic drink and had never been a drinking
man. He was a moderate smoker, did not keep late hours and was not given any
sort of dissipation or excess.

He lived at the Pensao Bitu. About ten days before his death he
complained of not feeling quite right, and kept to his room for a day. Then
he was out for a day or two, saying he felt better. Then he remained in his
room for a couple of days, and H. B. Fisher (of the Baldwin Locomotive Works),
who was also at the Bitu, called a physician. The physician thought the
ailment slight, prescribed some treatment and did not call again until sent
for two days later. Then a second physician was called in consultation. The
day before his death, the physicians diagnosed the case as yellow fever, and
Mr. George Schobinger, RIO DE JANEIRO:
2.
the following morning he was taken to the hospital where he died that
afternoon.

There was an autopsy at which, we were told, six or seven
physicians were present, and after which the certificate of death from
yellow fever was prepared.

The viscers were sent to Rio, and the newspapers subsequently
announced that the Federal sanitary authorities had decided that the
case was not yellow fever.

I saw Ashmore two or three times during his illness, but he did
not talk very rationally and I could not determine in my own mind how serious
his illness was. The last time I saw him was on the morning of the day he died.
At that time he seemed to be in a stupor and was not conscious of anyone's
presence. Everytime I saw him he had a bilious, almost jaundiced appearance.

Mr. H. B. Fisher may be able to tell you something more of this
case, but I do not see how you can get anything which would be of value to
the Rockefeller Institute except from the reports of the physicians.

The next death was that of an Englishman named Ritson, a salesman
for Gold Medal Flour. I never saw this man, and heard little of his illness,
but I think it was not called yellow fever by anyone. His death was assigned
to some affection of the liver.

The third was Walsh. You know quite as much of his case as I do
He complained of not feeling well on Friday, but stayed at his work through
Saturday. No one thought it worth while to call a physician until Sunday.
The physician said it was nothing. On Monday he still thought the illness
slight. On Tuesday he said the patient must be taken to Fortaleza at once.
Wednesday he was taken to Lavras and on Thursday morning he died on the train.
The two physicians, one who accompanied Walsh from Sao Goncalo and one at
Iguatu, gave the cause of death as “grippe intestinal”. They insisted upon
burial within two hours because they said the disease was very infectious.

p.hi: Mr. George Schobinger, RIO DE JANEIRO:

div1.p:
The fourth case was McGuckin. He left here on January 22, 1922,
in good health. He was, as you know, a robust, strong man. At Tutoya,
about thirty hours from here, he complained of chills down his spine. The
ship's doctor put him to bed and that night he was delirious. At Para, on
the 27th, the doctor on the Polycarp and the one on the ship to which he was
to transfer (the “Stephen”) diagnosed the case as yellow fever. He was
taken to the isolation hospital at Para, where he died on the morning of
February 7th. He was attended in Para by Dr. Carlos Ornstein and by the
physicians of the public health department. The cause of death was assigned
as “peste pneumonia”.

You may remember Day, who was employed for a time on our work
here and afterward went to Piranhas. During my absence in Para in February,
Day sailed from here for Recife. I later received a letter from the American
Consul at Recife advising that Day died of yellow fever the day after leaving
the steamer. I have no other information about this case.

At Sao Goncalo, G. W. Kaill was taken ill in the same way as Welsh
a short time after the latter's death. There is no doubt in my mind that
his life was saved by the prompt attendance of Dr. Jose Frota who went up
from here. I do not know how Dr. Frota diagnosed the case. Dr. Frota attended
both cases and diagnosed both as yellow fever.

W. D. Crider, Superintendent of operation of our cement mill,
arrived here May 30th, 1922. He had been here only a short time when he was
taken ill. The physician diagnosed his case as “grippe intestinal” and seemed
to think that he had no further obligation, having given a name to the disease.
In less than a week Crider was a more living skeleton, although a strong, robust
man when he arrived. Only the most careful nursing by a man who stayed by him
day and night saved his life. He was a month in recovering his strength.
Crider never drinks, smokes very little and does not dissipate his energies in
4.
Mr. George Schobinger, RIO DE JANEIRO:
any way. He is probably in the late forties in age.

A few weeks ago a young Englishman named Walker, whom I did not
know, complained one Saturday evening that he did not feel well. The
following Wednesday evening at six o'clock he died. The physician called
it yellow fever. The local head of the “Prophylaxia Rural”, after an
autopsy and a bacteriological investigation, said it was not yellow fever
but the “peste”, whatever that means.

The physicians here seem to be all alike in one respect. They
think they have done their duty when they give a name to the patient's
ailment. If another calls the disease by a different name they will argue for
a month about the name. The treatment and whether the patient recovers are
unimportant points.

We know only this: that there is some form of intestinal fever that
attacks very suddenly, especially unacclimated foreigners, and that it proves
fatal within a few days unless the patient is unusually fortunate. Whether they
call it yellow fever or toothache seems to me unimportant. They do little to
cure it and nothing to prevent it. If the physicians know why one patient re-
covers and another dies, they seem to think it is a State secret. They never
by any chance give the rest of us the benefit of the information so that we may
profit by it in the next case.

I do not believe the contents of this letter will be of much use to
Dr. Hackett, but this is all we really know, and it is worse than useless for
a layman to speculate on such matters. If you or Dr. Hackett can think of
anything further which would be useful and which we may be able to find out, I
shall be glad to follow up any suggestions.
